headline: Hillary Clinton Says, ‘I’m Not Running’ for President
summary: Hillary Clinton for the first time ruled out seeking the Democratic presidential nomination in 2020. Mrs. Clinton said she plans to “keep on working and speaking and standing up for what I believe.”

headline: Reserve Bank of Australia on Hold as Outlook Clouds
summary: Australia’s central bank left interest rate on hold Tuesday as expected, but continued to warn about rising risks to the economic outlook.

headline: Second HIV Patient May Be Cured After Stem-Cell Transplant
summary: A London man infected with HIV may be the second person to beat the virus that causes AIDS, researchers said, a finding advancing the costly and challenging search for a cure.

headline: China Cuts Growth Target Amid Challenging Economic Slowdown
summary: China lowered its economic growth target this year to between 6% and 6.5%, bowing to a deepening slowdown that can’t be quickly arrested without aggravating debt levels that are already high.

headline: Second Canadian Minister Resigns Over Judicial Interference Scandal
summary: A Canadian cabinet minister, Jane Philpott, resigned, saying she has lost confidence in the ruling Liberal Party over allegations it tried to interfere in a criminal prosecution of a global engineering and construction firm.

headline: Judge Questions Decision to Revoke U.S.-Born Woman’s Citizenship
summary: A federal judge on Monday questioned the State Department’s decision to revoke the citizenship of a U.S.-born woman who traveled to Syria to marry an Islamic State fighter and now wants to return home with a toddler son.

headline: U.S. Probes Titanium Imports in Possible Tariff Case
summary: The Commerce Department will look into potential national-security risks in imports of the metal at the request of domestic producer Timet.

headline: Democrats Aim to Block Trump Administration Move on Abortion Providers
summary: Democratic-led states are going to court to block a Trump administration plan to strip on-site abortion providers such as Planned Parenthood Federation of America of millions of taxpayer dollars for family planning, arguing the federal government is exceeding its authority to limit the federal funding.

headline: Regulators Target Energy-Efficient Home Improvements Loans
summary: Federal regulators are preparing to clamp down on a popular loan program used to finance solar panels and other energy-saving home improvements.

headline: Cheniere Deal With China Signals Country’s Key Role in LNG Exports
summary: Cheniere Energy’s expected $18 billion deal to supply natural gas to China signals the company’s growing bet on the country, and China’s emergence as a top market for U.S. gas exporters.

headline: Senate Will Block Trump’s Border-Wall Plan, McConnell Says
summary: Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said a resolution to block President Trump from declaring a national emergency would pass the GOP-controlled Senate, likely forcing the president to issue his first veto.

headline: AI Efforts at Large Companies May Be Hindered by Poor Quality Data
summary: Poor quality data could be keeping large firms from leveraging artificial intelligence and other digital tools to cut costs, boost revenue and stay competitive, according to a PricewaterhouseCoopers survey.

headline: Keeping Talent America Trains
summary: A study shows that foreign grads don’t steal American jobs.

headline: Wells Fargo Hires Strategic Enterprise Risk Chief
summary: Maria Teresa Tejada will oversee risks to Wells Fargo’s business lines, corporate functions and its strategic priorities, the San Francisco-based bank said. She also will direct enterprise risk programs and risk reporting and oversee strategic risk and reputation risk, the company said.

headline: Salesforce Raises Its Full-Year Sales Outlook as Profit Rises
summary: Salesforce reported a stronger profit and said it expects revenue to nearly double in four years, benefiting from companies shifting more of their spending to technology innovation.

headline: Document Requests Show House Panel’s Areas of Interest in Trump Probe
summary: The document requests issued Monday by the House Judiciary Committee cover a broad range of issues, as part of investigations the committee is starting into obstruction of justice, corruption and abuse of power.

headline: Hickenlooper Up the Middle
summary: The Coloradan won’t ban fossil fuels. Can he persuade Democrats?

headline: Kenneth Kiyul Lee’s White Privilege
summary: Liberals play the race card against a Korean-American immigrant.

headline: About Trump’s ‘Failure’ in Hanoi
summary: The president has left his negotiators better positioned for a good deal with Pyongyang.

headline: Allies Worry Over U.S. Public Opinion
summary: The gap between voters and foreign-policy elites shows little sign of closing.

headline: ‘Old’ the Phone, Another Scammer Is Calling
summary: As soon as I turned 70, offers rolled in for wheelchairs, cruises and cremation plans.

headline: Salesforce: Gravity Still Applies
summary: The cloud-software giant’s strong growth outlook still implies some slowdown.

headline: ‘Spies of No Country’ Review: The Dawn of Mossad
summary: Agents were taught rudimentary spycraft on a kibbutz, then sent off to gather intelligence and occasionally to blow something up.

headline: Tax Reform Unleashed the U.S. Economy
summary: The surge in private investment has brought big returns for households as well as the government.

headline: Behind China’s Desire for a Trade Deal With Trump
summary: President Xi’s nationalism is running into the reality of slower growth and a fear of political instability.

headline: What Your Doctor Isn’t Allowed to Tell You
summary: Badly designed electronic records can be hazardous to your health, but a gag clause protects the makers.

headline: De Blasio Defends Decision to Close Schools
summary: Critics said the mayor shouldn’t have called a snow day, after the storm fizzled out with only a fraction of the snowfall predicted.

headline: Panel Issues Last Permits for More Charter Schools in New York City
summary: A state panel approved seven more charter schools for New York City on Monday, using up all the permits allowed for the city and marking an end—at least for now—to the proliferation of charters here.

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Seeks U.S. Court’s Help Protecting Citgo
summary: Venezuela’s U.S.-backed opposition leaders asked a federal appeals court to refrain from carving up the country’s foreign assets, saying their loss would hurt the chances of political change in Caracas.

headline: New Treasury Rules Shape Corporate Tax Break
summary: The Treasury Department proposed the final major international-tax regulation under the 2017 tax law on Monday, outlining how businesses can claim a break related to certain foreign sales.

headline: Purdue Pharma Preparing Possible Bankruptcy Filing
summary: Purdue Pharma is working with advisers on a possible bankruptcy filing as it seeks to contain liability from suits alleging it fueled the U.S. opioid epidemic.

headline: U.S. Government Bonds Rise
summary: U.S. government bonds edged higher, with the yield on the benchmark 10-year Treasury note settling at 2.720%, following a modest bout of selling last week.

headline: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. Looks Like a Can’t-Miss Prospect
summary: Vladimir Guerrero Jr. appears ready for the majors after posting eye-popping numbers in the minors.

headline: Music to the Eyes
summary: After a three-year, multiphase overhaul, the Met’s instrument collection is more accessible and interesting than ever before.

headline: A Better Grid Is Possible for Green New Deal
summary: Technological revolutions have always had naysayers, and this transition will require rethinking how we operate the power grid.

headline: AOC Has Her 15 Minutes of Socialist Fame
summary: The more Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez’s wacky ideas get trashed by rational analysts, the more media buzz she gets. Presidential candidate Donald Trump retaught the lesson in 2016 that there is no such thing as bad publicity.

headline: California Court Backs Retiree Cut but Keeps Broader Worker Protections
summary: The California Supreme Court affirmed the state’s ability to roll back a specific pension benefit but left in place an influential rule offering public workers protection against cuts.

headline: The Lesson From Europe Is In What Policies to Avoid
summary: It’s doubtful that even the complete collapse of the EU would dissuade Democrats from following its lead into economic oblivion.

headline: Libya’s Largest Oil Field Restarts Production
summary: Libya’s National Oil has restarted limited production at its giant Sharara oil field, following the removal of gunmen who had occupied the field for three months.

headline: Judge Tosses Case Against Barclays Trader
summary: A federal judge dismissed without sending to the jury a case against a former senior Barclays trader accused of illegally trading in anticipation of a major client deal.

headline: Tornado Scientists Focus on Mobile Homes
summary: Scientists and researchers studying tornadoes are trying to develop new ways to give people living in mobile homes an earlier warning so they have more time to flee to safer places.

headline: After an Auditor Flunked Brazil Dam, Vale Found Another Who Passed It
summary: Vale, the owner of a mine-waste dam that collapsed this year, killing more than 180 people, dismissed an auditor that refused to certify the dam as safe in September, according to an initial probe by police and prosecutors.

headline: NYPD to Deploy Additional Officers to Reduce Rise in Murders and Rapes
summary: New York Police Department Commissioner James O’Neill announced Monday that he plans to dispatch additional uniformed officers to four precincts around the city to combat a surge in the number of murders and rapes this year.

headline: New House Election in North Carolina to Be Held on Sept. 10
summary: North Carolina officials set a Sept. 10 date for a new election for the nation’s last unresolved congressional race after the November results were thrown out over concerns of ballot tampering.

headline: Oil Rises on OPEC Cuts, Trade Hopes
summary: Oil prices rose on further production cuts by OPEC and fresh hopes a U.S.-China trade deal will be reached.

headline: Newmont Rejects Barrick Gold’s Takeover Bid
summary: Newmont Mining turned down a proposal from rival Barrick Gold to merge and create one of the world’s largest mining companies, a widely expected move.

headline: North Korea Still Using Uranium-Enrichment Facility, U.N. Agency Says
summary: North Korea is still using a uranium-enrichment facility at the heart of last week’s summit between President Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, the United Nations atomic agency said.

headline: Luke Perry Dead at 52 After Suffering Stroke
summary: A publicist for Luke Perry said the “Riverdale” and “Beverly Hills, 90210” star has died. The actor had been hospitalized since last week.

headline: Disney Cuts Compensation for Iger in Fox Deal
summary: Disney tweaked Robert Iger’s pay package, removing $13.5 million in potential salary and incentive awards available for the CEO after the company closes its acquisition of Fox assets.

headline: New Jersey Governor Again Seeks Higher Taxes on Wealthy
summary: Gov. Phil Murphy is proposing an increase in the top marginal tax rate to 10.75% from 8.97% for filers earning $1 million or more, a move estimated to bring in an additional $447 million annually in state income tax revenue.

headline: ‘Wolf of Wall Street’ Townhouse Sells for $12.65 Million
summary: The home of ex-banker Alan Wilzig is bought by wealthy Brazilians for dramatically less than the original $44 million asking price

headline: Top Berenberg Banker Investigated for Alleged Insider Trading
summary: German prosecutors are investigating a top executive of Germany’s Berenberg Bank for allegedly tipping off acquaintances on a sale of shares in Hapag-Lloyd that the bank was arranging.

headline: FDA Unveils Actions to Stem Youth Access to E-Cigarettes
summary: The Food and Drug Administration unveiled actions aimed at retailers and manufacturers to stem youth access to e-cigarettes.

headline: Russia Suspends Nuclear Missile Treaty With U.S.
summary: President Vladimir Putin formally ordered a suspension of Russia’s obligations under a Cold War-era nuclear treaty with the U.S., heightening the threat of a new arms race.

headline: Morrissey to Play the Great White Way
summary: Morrissey, the English singer-songwriter who launched his career with the Smiths before going solo, will play what is billed as a seven-show “residency” at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre this May 2 to 11.

headline: Treasurers Consider Changes to Bank Accounts, Cash Pools Ahead of Brexit
summary: A no-deal Brexit could force British and European treasurers to make changes to their bank accounts and cash pools to avoid higher fees and meet regulatory requirements.

headline: Greece Looks to Borrow Amid Buoyant Markets
summary: Greece said it plans to issue its first 10-year bond in nearly a decade, as the eurozone’s most-indebted country emerges from grueling bailouts and taps broad investor appetite for risky debt.

headline: Dollar Strengthens Slightly on Trade Hopes, Solid U.S. Data
summary: The dollar edged higher as investors reacted to signs of progress in trade talks between the U.S. and China and recent economic data.

headline: Do Robots Dream of Electric Tips?
summary: Success of food-delivery robots won’t be automatic.

headline: Philip Morris Cuts Profit Forecast After Canada Court Ruling
summary: Philip Morris International Inc. cut its profit outlook for the year and expects lower pretax earnings in the first quarter after a subsidiary and other tobacco companies lost a major legal appeal in Canada.

headline: Vatican to Open Archives on World War II Pope Pius XII
summary: Pope Francis said he would open the Vatican archives on Pope Pius XII, bowing to decades of requests from historians and Jewish groups who have questioned why the wartime pope stayed silent during the horrors of Nazi-controlled Europe.

headline: Algerians Renew Protests After President Defies Demands
summary: Algeria’s political crisis deepened after President Abdelaziz Bouteflika rejects demands to step down at the end of his term, prompting further protests that are convulsing the nation.

headline: Celgene Odds Are in Investors’ Favor
summary: Doubts over Bristol-Myers Squibb’s plan to buy Celgene, the largest pharmaceuticals merger on record, are giving brave investors a chance for a handsome profit.

headline: Ghosn Offers to Accept Camera Surveillance in Bid for Bail
summary: The former Nissan chairman has been detained by prosecutors since Nov. 19 and is determined to win bail after having two earlier applications turned down, his lawyer said.

headline: The Companies That Collect College Sports Secrets
summary: As scandals multiply in college sports, two companies aim to identify issues early through anonymous player feedback.

headline: Death Toll Climbs After Tornadoes Hit Southeast
summary: At least 23 people were killed on Sunday by tornadoes that swept through swaths of Alabama and Georgia.

headline: European Banks Tighten Belts to Fund Compliance Investments
summary: Financial institutions in Europe are investing more in staff and technology to spot financial crime following a recent string of money-laundering scandals. In some cases, they’re cutting costs elsewhere in the enterprise to fund the initiatives.

headline: How Trump Can Restart North Korean Diplomacy
summary: After last week’s fruitless Hanoi summit between President Trump and Kim Jong Un, the White House has two crucial problems to ponder as it attempts to move negotiations forward.

headline: A Novelist’s Detour to a Dystopian World
summary: John Lanchester’s new book, “The Wall,” imagines an island nation in self-imposed isolation after massive climate change.

headline: Facebook Sues Chinese Companies for Creating Fake Accounts
summary: Facebook and Instagram sued four companies and three people based in China for creating and selling fake accounts, likes and followers, according to a posting on the social media giant’s website.

headline: Stocks to Watch: AT&T, Facebook, Marriott, Campbell Soup
summary: AT&T, Facebook, Marriott, Mylan, and Campbell Soup are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Monday’s session.

headline: Democrats Turn to Online Tool for Organizing Volunteers
summary: MobilizeAmerica gives Democratic campaigns and progressive causes a centralized sign-up system for events, door-knocking and shifts calling and texting voters.

headline: U.S.-North Korea Nuclear Talks Must Resume Quickly, Says Worried South
summary: South Korea is pressing the U.S. and North Korea to return to negotiations to prevent the diplomatic detente from unraveling.

headline: U.S. Offers EU Olive Branch Restoring Embassy’s Status
summary: Frosty relations between the U.S. and the European Union warmed when Washington reversed its decision to downgrade the bloc’s embassy.

headline: Ted Baker CEO Resigns After Misconduct Probe
summary: Ray Kelvin, the founder and chief executive of British fashion retailer Ted Baker, has resigned with immediate effect following an investigation into his alleged misconduct.

headline: How Activists Buy Two Votes With One Share
summary: If you take big risks with other people’s money you should have your own fortune at risk too. Shareholders in targeted companies should think hard about activists’ true exposures when assessing their demands.

headline: Amid Measles Outbreaks, States Seek to Force Parents to Vaccinate Children
summary: Measles outbreaks nationwide have prompted several states to restrict or eliminate religious and personal-belief exemptions that parents use to avoid having their children vaccinated against the disease.

headline: U.S. Push on Food Trade Pressures EU
summary: U.S. and European trade negotiators, under growing domestic pressure over agriculture, are set to meet again this week as clashing demands threaten to rekindle a tit-for-tat economic war.

headline: What More Chinese Stocks in Global Benchmarks Means for Investors
summary: China’s once-isolated stock markets are becoming more relevant to international investors. In the latest shift, MSCI has given mainland shares more sway in some of its widely tracked indexes. Here’s what’s at stake.

headline: Chinese Stocks Hit Highest Since June on Hopes of Trade Breakthrough
summary: Shares rose on optimism about a long-awaited accord with the U.S. and hopes for fresh official support for the Chinese economy.

headline: Former Colorado Governor John Hickenlooper Enters 2020 Race
summary: Former Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper said he will seek the Democratic nomination for president in 2020, becoming the first member of the crowded field to run by trumpeting a record of working with Republicans.

headline: Westmoreland Announces Approval of Chapter 11 Plan
summary: Westmoreland Coal announced Monday that a bankruptcy court has approved the sale of its assets under its chapter 11 plan.

headline: Trump’s China Deal Could Punish U.S. Allies
summary: America first in a U.S.-China trade deal could deal a serious blow to the economies of friends around the world.

headline: Lyft’s IPO Has a Winner in Japan Already
summary: Rakuten, Japan’s answer to Amazon, deserves a closer look from investors, thanks to its 13% stake in Lyft.

headline: Global Acceptance of AI Grows, but Many Still Wary of Government Use
summary: AI acceptance levels vary significantly across cultures and regions, with the lowest AI acceptance rates in developed Western societies and the highest comfort levels in China, India and other non-Western cultures “that have higher reported or perceived levels of corruption,” according to the survey.

headline: Shopping at Discount Stores Could Help Get You a Loan
summary: Discover Financial Services, best known for its credit cards, plans to use artificial intelligence to assess hundreds of unusual characteristics about personal-loan applicants in an attempt to rein in losses.

headline: Derby’s Take: Former Fed No. 2 Lauds Powell’s Defense of Mandate
summary: The former second-in-command at the Federal Reserve had nothing but kind words for current leader Jerome Powell, and praised his excellent leadership in his first year of service.

headline: At Least 23 Killed After Tornadoes Hit Southeast
summary: At least 23 people were killed by tornadoes that swept through swaths of Alabama and Georgia. The most destruction appears to have been in Lee County, Ala., where two or more tornadoes touched down.

headline: Senior Goldman Banker in Asia to Join KKR
summary: Kate Richdale, a senior investment banker at Goldman Sachs in Asia, is leaving to join KKR, the U.S. private-equity giant said.

headline: What’s News: Business & Finance
summary: What’s News: Business & Finance

headline: What’s News: World-Wide
summary: What’s News: World-Wide

headline: Taboola Makes Acquisition to Bolster Its Take on Apple News
summary: Taboola is acquiring an Israeli team to bolster its young news recommendation service for users of Android phones.

headline: REITs Take On New Shine Amid Fed’s Softened View on Rates
summary: The Federal Reserve’s dovish tilt this year has been a boon for real-estate shares that were pressured by a threat of higher interest rates.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: AT&T Breaks Up Turner, Bulks Up Warner Bros. in Major Overhaul
summary: AT&T started reorganizing its WarnerMedia unit by combining its disparate networks and entertainment businesses, an overhaul that is expected to lead to cost-cutting and layoffs.

headline: Venezuela Opposition Leader Returns Home, Testing Maduro
summary: Opposition leader Juan Guaidó staged a dramatic return to Venezuela despite government threats to arrest him, energizing the country’s opposition and raising the stakes in the political showdown with President Nicolás Maduro’s government.

headline: Stocks Fall as Investors Pause on Trade
summary: Stocks fell, erasing early gains as investors continued to track trade negotiations between the U.S. and China as the two nations appear to inch closer to a pact.

headline: Will Democratic Primary Voters Tolerate a Liberal?
summary: A former Colorado governor will test whether the Sandernistas have taken over the party.

headline: ‘Invention and Design: Early Italian Drawings at the Morgan’ Review: Sketching the History of an Art Form
summary: An arresting exhibition demonstrates how Renaissance draftsmanship evolved from its comparatively formulaic roots in medieval manuscript illumination into an increasingly scientific and expressive discipline.

headline: China Accuses Detained Canadians of Espionage
summary: China accused two detained Canadians of working together to steal Chinese state secrets, moving ahead with a politically charged investigation seen as retribution for Canada’s arrest of a senior Huawei executive.

headline: The New Rapper Bridging Hip-Hop’s Generation Gap
summary: YBN Cordae’s unusual mix of old and new-school sounds has won him fans and industry support.

headline: How Accountants Break the Bad News About Tax Refunds: With Chocolate and Tissues
summary: Tax preparers are stocking up on supplies to comfort unhappy clients surprised by lower refunds this year. ‘We’ve talked about offering ice cream, or maybe even beer and wine.’

headline: High-Speed Rail in the U.S. Remains Elusive: Illinois Shows Why
summary: A $2 billion Chicago-St. Louis project will offer a top speed of just 110 mph and shave an hour off the trip. Few people are expected to use it. One problem: having to share the track with freight railroads.

headline: A Doctor’s Prescription for More AI in Medicine
summary: Eric Topol makes the case for how artificial intelligence can improve health care, despite privacy concerns.

headline: Nevada Is the Jackpot of Barrick’s Push for Newmont
summary: Barrick Gold’s bid to acquire rival gold producer Newmont Mining centers on a plan to combine portfolios and operations in the state of Nevada.

headline: Jordan Peele Is the New Master of Suspense
summary: In his highly anticipated film ‘Us,’ the director again uses horror to investigate the soul of contemporary America

headline: As Stock Exchanges Multiply, Miami Wants In on the Game
summary: Miami International Holdings is set to enter the stock-exchange business, planning to launch MIAX Equities Exchange even as some on Wall Street question whether another trading venue is necessary.

headline: Emily Weiss’s Glossier Play Will Be First in a Series of Brand Offshoots
summary: Five years after founding beauty brand Glossier, CEO Emily Weiss launches its first spinoff—a color cosmetics line inspired by ’70s nostalgia and school supplies. She talks to WSJ. Magazine about the advantage she says she has over big beauty companies.
